{{more footnotes|date=November 2018}} {{Expert needed|date=November 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Myron 'Max' Essex | image = Max essex.jpg | image_size = 160px | alt = | caption = Max Essex in Botswana, July 2007 | birth_name = Myron Elmer Essex | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1937|8|17|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Coventry, Rhode Island]] | residence = [[Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]], [[United States]] | nationality = American | other_names = Myron Essex, Max Essex | citizenship = United States | education = Doctorate of Veterinary Medicine, [[Michigan State University]], [[East Lansing, Michigan]], 1967; Ph.D., [[University of California, Davis]], 1970. | alma_mater = [[Michigan State University]]
(DVM, 1967), [[University of California, Davis]]
(1970, PhD) | occupation = Virologist, veterinarian, professor of immunology and public health | years_active = 1936 to present | employer = Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health | known_for = showed that a retrovirus caused immune suppression; scientific research relating to transmission of retroviruses and their links to certain diseases in both animals and human beings. * Work in [[Immunology]] and [[infectious disease]] (specifically retroviruses and HIV/AIDS) * Linked animal and human [[retrovirus]]es to [[immunosuppressive]] disease * Suspected that a retrovirus was the cause of [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] * Determined that [[HIV]] could be transmitted through blood and blood products to [[hemophilia]]cs and to recipients of blood transfusions. * Helped provide first evidence that HIV could be transmitted by [[heterosexual]] intercourse. | notable works = | spouse = Dr. Elizabeth Essex | partner = | children = 2 adult daughters; 5 grandchildren | relations = | callsign = | awards = * Ten (10) honorary degrees * Elected member, Institute of Medicine (IOM) of the National Academy of Sciences (now NASEM) * Fellow, American Academy of Microbiology * HIV Lifetime Achievement Award for Scientific Contributions from Institute of Human Virology (IHV), University of Maryland School of Medicine, November 2011 * Lifetime Achievement Award, AIDS Society of India, 2014 | website = | misc = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = | ethnicity = }} '''Myron Elmer "Max" Essex''' (born August 17, 1939) is the [[Mary Woodard Lasker]] Professor of Health Sciences in the Department of Immunology and Infectious Diseases at [[Harvard University]], Chair of the [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]] AIDS Initiative (HAI) in the Department of Immunology and Infectious Diseases,[http://www.aids.harvard.edu/ Harvard School of Public Health AIDS Initiative] and Chair of the Botswana–Harvard AIDS Institute in [[Gaborone]], [[Botswana]]. Essex was one of the first to link animal and human [[retrovirus]]es to [[immunosuppressive]] disease, to suspect that a retrovirus was the cause of [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]], and to determine that [[HIV]] could be transmitted through blood and blood products to [[hemophilia]]cs and recipients of blood transfusions. With collaborators, Essex also provided the first evidence that HIV could be transmitted by [[heterosexual]] intercourse. In 1984, Essex identified [[gp120]], the virus surface protein that is used worldwide for blood screening, HIV detection, and epidemiological monitoring. With collaborators, he discovered the first [[simian immunodeficiency virus]], as well as [[HIV-2]]. Since 1986, he has developed programs for AIDS collaboration in [[Senegal]], [[Thailand]], [[Botswana]], [[India]], [[Mexico]], and [[China]]. In 1996, Essex helped establish the Botswana–Harvard Partnership for HIV Research and Education (now the Botswana–Harvard AIDS Institute). This is a collaboration between the Ministry of Health in Botswana and HAI. ==Biography== Essex was born in [[Coventry, Rhode Island]] in 1939.[https://books.google.com/books?id=92bJlWbPeKMC&q=%22Essex,+myron+elmer%22+1939&dq=%22Essex,+myron+elmer%22+1939&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Fd6WUfOFI4jjiwL6tIGYBQ&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAw Who's Who in the World: 199l-1992] Essex earned his [[Doctor of veterinary medicine|DVM]] from [[Michigan State University]] in 1967. He earned his Ph.D. from [[University of California, Davis]], in 1970. He has been married to Elizabeth Essex since 1967. They have two daughters and five grandchildren.[https://aids.harvard.edu/max-essex-the-persistent-investigator/ Henry MS. Max Essex: The Persistent Investigator. March 11, 2016. HAI Blog. Spotlight, Winter 2016.] Essex holds ten [[honorary doctorate]]s[https://aids.harvard.edu/max-essex-the-persistent-investigator/ Henry MS. Max Essex: The Persistent Investigator. March 11, 2016. HAI Blog. Spotlight, Winter 2016.] and 15 patents and has received the [[Lasker Award]],[http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/1986clinical.htm 1986 Lasker Award] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716162257/http://www.laskerfoundation.org/awards/1986clinical.htm |date=2010-07-16 }} the highest medical research award given in the United States, jointly with [[Robert Gallo]] and [[Luc Montagnier]] in 1986. He has published over 500 papers and 12 books, including two editions of ''AIDS in Africa'' ({{ISBN|0306466996}}), and his latest, ''Saturday Is for Funerals'' ({{ISBN|0674050770}}). Essex has worked in twelve (12) different nations as a [[veterinarian]] and [[virologist]]: Botswana, China, Colombia, India, Japan, Nigeria, Senegal, Taiwan, Tanzania, Thailand, U.S., Zaire.[https://aids.harvard.edu/max-essex-the-persistent-investigator/ Henry MS. Max Essex: The Persistent Investigator. March 11, 2016. HAI Blog. Spotlight, Winter 2016.] His 45 years of working papers, the Myron Essex papers, 1949-1996, are archived in the Countway Library's Center for the History of Medicine through funding by a Hidden Collections grant from the [[Harvard University Library]] (HUL) within The Maximizing Microbiology: Molecular Genetics, Cancer, and Virology, 1936-2000 project. In addition to the Myron Essex papers (1949-1996), the project has already led to the processing of collections of several other microbiologists, including those of Bernard D. Davis, Arthur B. Pardee, Francesc Duran i Reynals, and Luigi Gorini. Essex serves on the Library's Archives Committee.[https://aids.harvard.edu/people/max-essex/ Harvard AIDS Institute Profile Page for Max Essex] He has been the primary mentor to eight (80) Postdocs and to 34 Doctoral students. He has authored 629 research papers, forty (40) of which have been published in Science or Nature.[https://aids.harvard.edu/max-essex-the-persistent-investigator/ Henry MS. Max Essex: The Persistent Investigator. March 11, 2016. HAI Blog. Spotlight, Winter 2016.] His 45 years of working papers, the Myron Essex papers, 1949-1996, are archived in the Countway Library's Center for the History of Medicine through funding by a Hidden Collections grant from the [[Harvard University Library]] (HUL) within The Maximizing Microbiology: Molecular Genetics, Cancer, and Virology, 1936-2000 project. In addition to the Myron Essex papers (1949-1996), the project has already led to the processing of collections of several other microbiologists, including those of Bernard D. Davis, Arthur B. Pardee, Francesc Duran i Reynals, and Luigi Gorini. Essex serves on the Library's Archives Committee. In 2018 Dr. Essex announced his retirement plans.[https://aids.harvard.edu/max-essex-the-persistent-investigator/ Henry MS. Max Essex: The Persistent Investigator. March 11, 2016. HAI Blog. Spotlight, Winter 2016.] ==Awards== * Elected member, Institute of Medicine (IOM) of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS, now NASEM){{cn|date=November 2018}} * Fellow, American Academy of Microbiology{{cn|date=November 2018}} * HIV Lifetime Achievement Award for Scientific Contributions from the Institute of Human Virology (IHV) at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, November 2011[https://aids.harvard.edu/essex-receives-lifetime-achievement-award-spotlight-fall-2011/ Henry MS. Essex Receives Lifetime Achievement Award. December 1, 2011. HAI Blog] * Lifetime Achievement Award, AIDS Society of India, 2014 (in Kolkata). The plaque reads “For his exemplary contribution towards research in HIV/AIDS and for his outstanding leadership in public health.”{{cn|date=November 2018}} ==Awards named for Max Essex== * Essex Fellowship for Students from Africa, [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]], annually since 2007 ==External links== *[http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/faculty/myron-essex/ Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health AIDS Initiative list of Associated Researchers]*[https://aids.harvard.edu/hai-founded-30-years-ago-this-week/ Announcement of 1988 founding of HAI, the Harvard AIDS Institute] - "Bok named Myron (Max) Essex, a virologist at the Harvard School of Public Health (HSPH), to lead the Institute. According to Essex, “HAI was the brainchild of Harvey Fineberg,” who was HSPH Dean at the time." *[https://connects.catalyst.harvard.edu/Profiles/display/Person/71250 Harvard Catalyst Profile Page for Max Essex] *[https://aids.harvard.edu/people/max-essex/ Harvard AIDS Institute Profile Page for Max Essex] *[https://cms.www.countway.harvard.edu/wp/?p=12647 Coup E. {{Unreferenced|date=December 2007}} The '''Haughty Maiden of Logres''' is a character from [[Arthurian legend]], appearing in [[Chrétien de Troyes]]' ''[[Perceval, the Story of the Grail]]'' and works based on it. She is left nameless in Chrétien's unfinished romance, but [[Wolfram von Eschenbach]], who reworked the tale for the [[German language|German]] epic ''[[Parzival]]'', calls her '''Orgeluse''' (taken from ''Orgueilleuse'', the French word for "haughty").
In Chrétien's work, [[Gawain]] meets the Haughty Maiden while travelling; she treats him with contempt and scorn. Despite her humiliating treatment, Gawain acts with unfailing courtesy towards her, accepting her insults with grace.
Following her instructions to search for a nearby castle by a [[Ford (crossing)|ford]], Gawain encounters a knight who tells him that he is either very brave or foolish, for everyone who has tried to cross the perilous ford between them had drowned. Gawain realises the damsel had tried to do away with him. The knight offers to lead Gawain to a bridge, but the hero chooses to jump the ford on his horse [[Gringolet]]. He fails once, but succeeds the second time, and when he returns to the Haughty Maiden, she finally gives in and asks for forgiveness for treating him so poorly. She explains that her attitude was the result of tragic circumstances; the knight [[Guiromelant]] tried to win her love by killing her first suitor in single combat. Gawain sets off to avenge the fallen knight, but matters are complicated when Guiromelant reveals his love for Gawain's sister. The poem breaks off before the matter is resolved, though a later author tied up some of the loose threads in the [[Perceval, the Story of the Grail#First Continuation|First Continuation]] of ''Perceval''.
Wolfram expands the story and brings it to completion. He explains that the [[Fisher King|Wounded King]] Anfortas had been injured fighting for Orgeluse, and was now waiting for [[Percival|Parzival]] (Percival) to heal him. Gawain and Orgeluse express their love for each other, and eventually peace is made between the lady and Guiromelant. Orgeluse marries Gawain while Guiromelant marries the champion's sister.

'''''Otros Aires''''' is an [[Argentina|Argentine]] XXI century [[Tango music]] project, founded in 2003 in [[Barcelona]] by Argentine musician/architect Miguel Di Genova.
''Otros Aires'' mixes the first [[Argentine tango|''tangos'']] and [[Milonga (music)|''milongas'']] structures from the beginning of the last century ([[Carlos Gardel|Gardel]], Razzano, D'Arienzo, etc.) with electronic sequences, melodies and lyrics of the 21st century.
This project counts with many collaborators like: Diego Ramos (Piano & arrangements), Chloë Pfeiffer (Piano), Lalo zanelli (Piano), Martin Bruhn (Drums), Martin Paladino (Drums), Manu Mayol (Drums & production) Pablo Potenzoni (Drums), Javier Saume Mazzei (Drums), Christian Maturano (Drums), Carlos Ocorso (Percussion), Hugo Satorre (Bandoneon), Lisandre Donoso (bandoneon), Herve Esquis (bandoneon), Emmanuel Trifilio (bandoneon), Simone Van Der Veerden (bandoneon), Joe Power (Harmonica), Nick Wadlew (Cover Drawings), Pablo Meketa (Cover Drawings), Marcelo Sofia (Cover Arts), Charly Fiorentino (Cover Arts) Miru Trigo (Photography) and Santiago Saponi (Video Director) between others.
On December 11, 2004, known as "Tango day", ''Otros Aires'' presented its first CD at the Carlos Gardel's House Museum, commemorating the birthday of the singer.
With about 40 tours around, including more that 200 cities of Europe, North America and South America, OTROS AIRES was presented in some of the most important venues and world music festivals of the world like: Lincoln Center (NYC), Dublin National Concert Hall, Bardentreffen Festival (Nuremberg), Amsterdam Roots Festival, Greensound Festival (Bucharest), Pirineos Sur Festival (Spain), between others and also at the most relevant tango festivals of the planet including Buenos Aires Tango Festival several times.
OTROS AIRES songs are featured in TV shows like ¨Dancing with the Stars¨ and ¨America´s Got Talent¨ in US and ¨Strictly Come Dancing¨ in UK.

[[Star Awards for Top 10 Most Popular Male Artistes|Top 10 Most Popular Male Artistes]] ''' }} '''Qi Yuwu''' (born 28 November 1976) is a [[Mediacorp]] actor based in [[Singapore]]. He is a permanent resident of Singapore and a contracted artiste under Beijing Enlight Media Group. ==Life and career== Qi studied at [[Guangzhou Sport University|Guangzhou Physical Education Institute]] before moving to Singapore. He won the title of Champion and Mr Personality in the China Round of [[Star Search Singapore|Asian Star Search]] in 1999. Previously, Qi worked as a model and played the lead role in a [[Guangzhou]]-produced television series, before signing on a contract with the [[Television Corporation of Singapore]] (now [[Mediacorp]]). In 2000, Qi was cast in his debut role as [[Lu Xiaofeng#Supporting characters|Sikong Zhaixing]] in ''[[Master Swordsman Lu Xiaofeng]]'' with other actors from Singapore and the Asian-Pacific region. Following that, Qi was cast in ''Dare To Strike'', another Singapore-Hong Kong co-produced television series. Apart from acting in Singaporean television dramas, Qi has also starred in international films, some of which were produced by [[Mediacorp Raintree Pictures]].{{cite news|title=Qi Yuwu's Movie Ambition|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/entertainment/view/313735/1/.html|publisher=[[Channel News Asia]]|date=27 November 2007}} He also starred 2011 in the Australian [[3-D film|3-D]] [[Horror film]] [[Bait 3D]].[http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/55602/official-trailer-bait-3d-swims Official Trailer for Bait 3D Swims In] In January 2013, Qi worked with renowned Chinese artist, [[Feng Zhengjie]], to present their artwork, 'Showcase on Print' for the inaugural [[Art Apart Fair|Worlds Apart Fair]]. In April 2013, Qi began dating co-star [[Joanne Peh]] (白薇秀). On 9 September 2014, the couple got married in front of the Merlion statue in a "hush-hush ceremony" at The Mövenpick Heritage Hotel Sentosa. On 28 January 2015, the couple announced that they were expecting their first child.{{cite news|title=Joanne Peh, Qi Yuwu expecting SG50 baby|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/joanne-peh-qi-yuwu/1620940.html|accessdate=29 January 2015|agency=Channel NewsAsia|date=28 January 2015}} On 7 August 2015, Yuwu and Joanne welcomed a baby girl at Mount Elizabeth Hospital. At [[Star Awards 2016]] Yuwu received his [[Star Awards for All-Time Favourite Artiste|All-Time Favourite Artiste]] award and also won his second Best Actor award for his role as Jason Lam in [[The Dream Makers II]]. In October 2016, Yuwu and Joanne announced that they were expecting a second child, and on 21 April 2017 she gave birth to a boy.{{ cite news|title=Joanne Peh and Qi Yuwu welcome baby boy|url= http://m.todayonline.com/entertainment/celebrity/joanne-peh-and-qi-yuwu-welcome-baby-boy|date=21 April 2017}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Carol Wells | children = 3 | education = [[Baylor University]]
[[Duke University]] ([[Doctor of Medicine|MD]]) | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | signature = Rand Paul's Signature.svg | website = {{url|paul.senate.gov|Senate website}} }} '''Randal Howard''' "'''Rand'''" '''Paul''' (born January 7, 1963) is an American politician and physician serving as the [[Seniority in the United States Senate|junior]] [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from [[Kentucky]] since 2011, alongside Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]]. He is the son of former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Ron Paul]] of [[Texas]]. Born in [[Pittsburgh|Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], Paul attended [[Baylor University]] and is a graduate of the [[Duke University School of Medicine]]. Paul began practicing [[ophthalmology]] in 1993 in [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]], and established his own [[clinic]] in December 2007. In 2010, Paul entered politics by [[United States Senate election in Kentucky, 2010|running for a seat]] in the [[United States Senate]]. A [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], Paul has described himself as a Constitutional conservative and a supporter of the [[Tea Party movement]]. He has advocated for a [[balanced budget amendment]], [[term limit]]s, and privacy reform. Paul [[Rand Paul presidential campaign, 2016|was a candidate]] for the Republican nomination at the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 US presidential election]]. He suspended his campaign in February 2016, after finishing in fifth place out of 12 Republican candidates at the [[Iowa Republican caucuses, 2016|Iowa caucuses]]. {{Rand Paul sidebar}} ==Early life== Randal Howard Paul was born on January 7, 1963, in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], to Carol (née Wells) and [[Ron Paul]], who is also a politician and physician. The elder Paul was a [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[Texas]] and ran for President of the United States three times.{{cite web|last=Alessi|first=Ryan| url=http://www.kentucky.com/2010/04/20/1231313/pauls-small-government-message.html#more|title=Paul's top goal is to cut federal spending|publisher = ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]''|access-date=December 16, 2010|date=September 13, 2010}} The middle child of five, his siblings are Ronald "Ronnie" Paul Jr., Lori Paul Pyeatt, Robert Paul, and Joy Paul-LeBlanc.{{cite web|last=Stonington|first=Joel| url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/10/04/how-old-is-rand-paul|title=How Old Is Rand Paul?|website=[[Politics Daily]].com|access-date=December 16, 2010|date=October 4, 2010}} Paul was [[baptism|baptized]] in the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]{{cite web|last=O'Bryan|first=Jason|url=http://www.politicsdaily.com/2010/10/25/what-is-rand-pauls-religion|title=What Is Rand Paul's Religion?|website=PoliticsDaily.com|access-date=January 31, 2011|date=October 25, 2010}} and identified as a practicing Christian as a teenager.{{cite news|last=Wolfson|first=Andrew|title =Rand Paul rides tide of anti-Washington sentiment|work=[[The Courier-Journal]]|location=Louisville, Kentucky|date=October 18, 2010|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/2166776301.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+18%2C+2010&author=Andrew+Wolfson&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=n%2Fa&desc=Rand+Paul+rides+tide+of+anti-Washington+sentiment|access-date=February 23, 2011}} Despite his father's [[Libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]] views and strong support for [[Individual and group rights|individual rights]],{{cite web|last=Healy|first=Gene|authorlink=Gene Healy|title=Rand Paul, Anti-Incumbent Republican|publisher=[[Cato Institute]]|date=May 18, 2010|url=http://www.cato.org/pub_display.php?pub_id=11819|access-date=February 8, 2011|quote=Given father Ron's libertarian convictions, people often assume that he is named after the self-styled 'radical for capitalism' who wrote ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]''.}} the novelist [[Ayn Rand]] was not the inspiration for his first name. Growing up, he went by "Randy",{{cite news|last=Leibovich|first=Mark|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/06/us/politics/06paul.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|title=For Paul Family, Libertarian Ethos Began at Home|work=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=June 6, 2010|date=June 6, 2010}} but his wife shortened it to "Rand."{{cite web|last=Rettig|first=Jessica|url=http://politics.usnews.com/news/articles/2010/06/03/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-rand-paul.html|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About Rand Paul |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|access-date=December 12, 2010|date=June 3, 2010}}{{cite web|last=Burnette|first=Eric|url=http://www.louisville.com/content/gospel-according-paul-louisville-magazines-inside-look-us-senate-candidate-rand-paul-news|title=The Gospel According to Paul|work=[[Louisville Magazine]]|access-date=December 30, 2010|date=September 7, 2010}} The Paul family moved to [[Lake Jackson, Texas]], in 1968, where he was raised{{cite news|last=Horowitz|first=Jason| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/03/AR2010020303643.html|title=Running for Senate, Rand Paul lights a fire under Kentucky GOP|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=February 23, 2011|date=February 4, 2010}}{{cite web|last=Wolfford|first=David| url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/229456/rand-against-machine/david-wolfford|title=Rand against the Machine|work=[[National Review]]|access-date=February 23, 2011|date=April 5, 2010}} and where his father began a medical practice and for an extent of time was the only [[Obstetrics|obstetrician]] in [[Brazoria County, Texas|Brazoria County]].{{Cite book|last=Watterson|first=Mark|title =Don't Weep for Me, America: How Democracy in America Became the Prince (While We Slept)| publisher=Dorrance Publishing|year=2008|page=203|isbn=978-0-8059-7890-2}}; {{cite news|last=Sherman|first=Jerome L.|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07215/806597-176.stm|title=Texas congressman brings presidential campaign to hometown|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|access-date=February 12, 2011|date=August 3, 2007|quote=He and his wife decided to settle in the southeastern Texan town of Lake Jackson, near the site of his military service. For a period, Paul was the only obstetrician in Brazoria County, and he delivered as many as 50 babies a month.}} When Rand was 13, his father was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives]].{{cite web|last=Straub|first=Bill| url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2010/sep/19/rand-paul/|title=Off and running: Rand Paul|work= [[Evansville Courier & Press]] |access-date=February 23, 2011|date=September 19, 2010}} That same year, Paul attended the [[1976 Republican National Convention]], where his father headed [[Ronald Reagan]]'s Texas delegation.{{cite news|last1=Lizza|first1=Ryan|title=The Revenge of Rand Paul| url= http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/10/06/revenge-rand-paul|access-date=October 8, 2014|work= [[The New Yorker]]|date=October 6, 2014}} The younger Paul often spent summer vacations interning in his father's congressional office.{{cite news|title=Rand Paul's Mixed Inheritance| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/26/us/politics/rand-pauls-mixed-inheritance.html?hpw&rref=us&_r=0| access-date= January 27, 2014| newspaper=The New York Times|date=January 25, 2014|author-link1=Sam Tanenhaus|first1=Sam |last1=Tanenhaus| author-link2=Jim Rutenberg|first2=Jim |last2= Rutenberg}} In his teenage years, Paul studied the [[Austrian School|Austrian economists]] that his father respected, as well as the writings of [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivist]] philosopher Ayn Rand. Paul went to [[Brazoswood High School]] and was on the swimming team and played defensive back on the football team. Paul attended [[Baylor University]] from fall 1981 to summer 1984 and was enrolled in the honors program. During the time he spent at Baylor, he was involved in the swim team and the [[Young Conservatives of Texas]] and was a member of a secret organization known as [[The NoZe Brotherhood]].{{cite web| last= Brammer| first= Jack| url=http://www.kentucky.com/2010/08/11/1385157/paul-calls-allegations-in-gq-story.html|title=Paul: GQ allegations 'absolutely untrue'|work=Lexington Herald-Leader|access-date=February 27, 2011|date=September 28, 2010}} He regularly contributed to ''[[The Baylor Lariat]]'' student newspaper. Paul dropped out of Baylor without completing his [[baccalaureate degree]],{{cite news|title=Rand Paul's claim – twice in one day – that he has a biology degree|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/fact-checker/wp/2015/02/13/rand-pauls-claim-twice-in-one-day-that-he-has-a-biology-degree/?postshare=8041423829610892|access-date=February 13, 2015|newspaper=The Washington Post|first=Glenn|last=Kessler}} when he was accepted into his father's alma mater, the [[Duke University School of Medicine]], which, at the time, did not require an undergraduate degree for admission to its graduate school. He earned an [[Doctor of Medicine|M.D.]] degree in 1988 and completed his [[Residency (medicine)|residency]] in 1993.{{cite web| last= Brammer| first= Jack|date=August 5, 2010 |title=Contrary to some media reports, Rand Paul has no bachelor's degree| url=http://www.kentucky.com/2010/08/05/1377392/contrary-to-some-media-reports.html|work=Lexington Herald-Leader|access-date=September 10, 2010}} ==Medical career== After completing his residency in ophthalmology, Paul moved to [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]]. He has held a state-issued medical license since moving there in 1993.{{cite news|last=Gerth|first=Joseph|title=Rand Paul's ophthalmology certification not recognized by national clearinghouse|publisher=''The Courier-Journal''|date=June 14, 2010| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/2059232451.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jun+14%2C+2010&author=Joseph+Gerth&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=n%2Fa&desc=Rand+Paul%27s+ophthalmology+certification+not+recognized+by+national+clearinghouse|access-date=July 2, 2010}} He received his first job from John Downing of Downing McPeak Vision Centers, which brought him to Bowling Green after completing his residency. Paul worked for Downing for about five years before parting ways. Afterwards, he went to work at the Graves Gilbert Clinic, a private medical group in Bowling Green, for 10 years before creating his own practice in a converted one-story house across the street from Downing's office. After his election to the U.S. Senate, he merged his practice with Downing's medical practice.{{cite web|last=Harmon|first=Hayley|title=Rand Paul's Practice Merges with Downing-McPeak|publisher=[[WBKO]]|date=January 5, 2011|url=http://www.wbko.com/home/headlines/Rand_Pauls_Practice_Merges_with_Downing-McPeak_112968089.html|access-date=March 12, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107095436/http://www.wbko.com/home/headlines/Rand_Pauls_Practice_Merges_with_Downing-McPeak_112968089.html|archivedate=January 7, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Paul has faced two malpractice lawsuits between 1993 and 2010; he was cleared in one case while the other was settled for $50,000.{{cite web|last=Van Benschoten|first=Amanda|title=Rand Paul's political rise surprises even those in Bowling Green|publisher=''The Courier-Journal''|date=July 5, 2010|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20100705/NEWS0106/7050340/Rand-Paul-s-political-rise-surprises-even-those-Bowling-Green|access-date =March 6, 2011}} His medical work has been praised by Downing and he has medical privileges at two Bowling Green hospitals. Paul specializes in cataract and glaucoma surgeries, LASIK procedures, and corneal transplants. As a member of the Bowling Green Noon [[Lions Clubs International|Lions Club]], Paul founded the Southern Kentucky Lions Eye Clinic in 2009 to help provide eye surgery and exams for those who cannot afford to pay.{{Cite news| url=http://www.kulr8.com/news/state/13944012.html|publisher=[[KULR-TV]]|date=January 21, 2008|access-date=April 4, 2009|agency=Associated Press|title=Son of long-shot presidential hopeful to visit Montana|location=[[Billings, Montana]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525190721/http://www.kulr8.com/news/state/13944012.html|archivedate=May 25, 2010}} Paul won the Melvin Jones Fellow Award for Dedicated Humanitarian Services from the Lions Club International Foundation for his work establishing the Southern Kentucky Lions Eye Clinic.{{cite news|last1=Thomason|first1=Andrew|title=Rand Paul's balancing act|url=http://www.bgdailynews.com/news/rand-paul-s-balancing-act/article_3134ce1f-d32b-5098-8127-2a8f8b9dd592.html|access-date=August 15, 2014|publisher=Park City Daily News|date=September 5, 2010}} ===National Board of Ophthalmology=== In 1995, Paul passed the [[American Board of Ophthalmology]] (ABO) boards on his first attempt and earned board-certification under the ABO for 10 years.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} Prior to this, in 1992, the ABO had changed its certification program, which had previously awarded lifetime certifications, instead requiring doctors to recertify every 10 years. Those who had already been given lifetime certification were allowed to keep it (according to the ABO, they would not legally have been able to rescind these certifications). Shortly after this change, Paul began a campaign to protest it. This effort culminated in 1997 with him creating, "along with 200 other young ophthalmologists", the National Board of Ophthalmology (NBO) to offer an alternative certification system, at a cost substantially lower than that of the ABO.{{cite news|first=David A.|last=Fahrenthold|title=How Rand Paul tried to lead an eye doctors' rebellion|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/how-rand-paul-tried-to-lead-an-eye-doctors-rebellion/2015/02/01/010994da-9cd6-11e4-a7ee-526210d665b4_story.html|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=February 1, 2015|access-date=April 9, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Weigel|first=David|title=Rand Paul: I passed my ophthalmology certification, but took a stand against the way the board operates|publisher=''The Washington Post''|date=June 14, 2010|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/right-now/2010/06/rand_paul_i_passed_my_opthamal.html|access-date=March 22, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Montopoli|first=Brian|title=Rand Paul's Addresses Ophthalmology Certification Questions|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20007639-503544.html|publisher=CBS News|access-date=October 18, 2013|date=June 14, 2010}} Its certification exam, an open book take-home test, was described by one taker as "probably harder" and "more clinically relevant" than the ABO's exam. Named board members were Paul, his wife, and his father-in-law.{{cite news|title=Rand Paul's Doctor Credentials Questioned for Lacking Top Board's Certification|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2010/06/14/rand-pauls-doctor-credentials-questioned-lacking-boards-certification|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News Channel|access-date=October 18, 2013|date=June 14, 2010}} The NBO was, itself, never accepted as an accrediting entity by organizations such as the [[American Board of Medical Specialties]], and its certification was considered invalid by many hospitals and insurance companies. Paul let his own ABO certification lapse in 2005, which did not affect his practice in Kentucky; the state does not require board certification. By Paul's estimate, about 50 or 60 doctors were certified by the NBO. The NBO was incorporated in 1999, but Paul allowed it to be dissolved in 2000 when he did not file the required paperwork with the Kentucky Secretary of State's office. He later recreated the board in 2005, but it was again dissolved in 2011.{{cite web|title=Certificate of Dissolution|url=https://app.sos.ky.gov/corpscans/24/0479924-09-99999-20111101-ADS-4902880-PU.pdf|publisher=Kentucky Secretary of State|access-date=February 5, 2013}} ==Political activism== Paul was head of the local chapter of the [[Young Conservatives of Texas]] during his time at [[Baylor University]]. In 1984, Paul took a semester off to aid his father's primary challenge to Republican Senator [[Phil Gramm]]. While attending [[Duke University School of Medicine]], Paul volunteered for his father's [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988]] [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] [[Ron Paul presidential campaign, 1988|presidential campaign]]. In response to President [[George H. W. Bush|Bush]]'s breaking his election promise to not [[Read my lips: no new taxes|raise taxes]], Paul founded the North Carolina Taxpayers Union in 1991. In 1994, Paul founded the anti-tax organization Kentucky Taxpayers United (KTU), and was chair of the organization from its inception. He has often cited his involvement with KTU as the foundation of his involvement with state politics.{{cite news| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2010/10/14/rand-pauls-antitax-group-has-been-inactive-for-years/|title=Rand Paul's Antitax Group Has Been Inactive for Years|first=Douglas A.|last=Blackmon|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=October 14, 2010|access-date=November 3, 2010}} The group{{Cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&s_site=kentucky&p_multi=LH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB7405EA721DDBE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work = Lexington Herald-Leader|title=56 Honored by Taxpayers Group|page=C4|date=April 16, 1996|access-date=April 4, 2009}}{{Cite news| url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&s_site=kentucky&p_multi=LH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB7350C1BCFAFDF&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work = Lexington Herald-Leader|title=Legislators Honored as Anti-Tax 'Heroes' But Several Honorees Recently Voted for Tax|page=A12|date=April 13, 2000|access-date=April 4, 2009}} examined Kentucky legislators' records on taxation and spending and encouraging politicians to publicly pledge to vote uniformly against tax increases.{{Cite news| url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-72916086.html|title=8 Legislators Named Friends of Taxpayers|quote=Recognized by Kentucky Taxpayers United were Sens. Gex 'Jay' Williams and [[Dick Roeding]] and Reps. Charlie Walton, Paul Marcotte, Katie Stine, Tom Kerr, Dick Murgatroyd and Jon David Reinhardt {{interp|...}} Rand Paul, the group's chairman, said the organization did the ranking so voters could see where their lawmakers stand on the issues|last=Collins|first=Michael|work=[[Kentucky Post]]|location=[[Covington, Kentucky]]|date=April 16, 1996|access-date=April 4, 2009}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-63443974.html|title=Not One Cent More|date=March 29, 2000|access-date=April 4, 2009|work=Kentucky Post|last=Paul|first=Rand}} Paul managed his father's successful [[Texas's 14th congressional district#1996|1996 Congressional campaign]], in which the elder Paul returned to the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] after a twelve-year absence. The elder Paul defeated incumbent [[Party switching in the United States|Democrat-turned-Republican]] [[Greg Laughlin]] in the Republican primary, despite Laughlin's support from the [[National Republican Congressional Committee|NRCC]] and Republican leaders such as [[Newt Gingrich]] and [[George W. Bush]]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reported in 2010 that, although Paul had told a Kentucky television audience as recently as September 2009 that KTU published ratings each year on state legislators' tax positions and that "we've done that for about 15 years", the group had stopped issuing its ratings and report cards after 2002 and had been legally dissolved by the state in 2000 after failing to file registration documents. Paul spoke on his father's behalf when his father was campaigning for office,{{cite web| url=http://www.ronpaul2008.com/events/rand-paul/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123211511/http://www.ronpaul2008.com/events/rand-paul|archivedate=January 23, 2008|title=Dr. Rand Paul: Upcoming Events|publisher=[[Ron Paul 2008]]|access-date=December 20, 2007}} including throughout the elder Paul's run in the 2008 presidential election, during which Rand campaigned door-to-door in New Hampshire{{Cite news| url=http://www.bgdailynews.com/articles/2007/06/06/news/news9.txt|work=[[Bowling Green Daily News]]|last= Gaines| first= Jim| title= Bowling Green ophthalmologist says father, Rep. Ron Paul, R-Texas, stands a good chance in N.H. primary election|date=June 6, 2007|access-date=April 4, 2009}} and spoke in Boston at a fundraising rally for his father on the 234th anniversary of the [[Boston Tea Party]].{{cite news|last=Santora|first=Marc|title=Reinventing the revolution| url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/12/16/reinventing-the-revolution/|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 16, 2007}} In February 2014, Paul joined the [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]]-affiliated conservative advocacy group [[FreedomWorks]] in filing a [[Class action|class-action]] lawsuit charging that the federal government's bulk collection of Americans' phone records [[phone log|metadata]] is a violation of the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourth Amendment]] of the U.S. Constitution.{{cite news|last=Glueck|first=Katie|title=Rand Paul files class-action suit vs NSA| url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/rand-paul-national-security-agency-lawsuit-103423.html|newspaper=Politico|date=February 12, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Fuller|first=Jaime|title=Rand Paul files suit against Obama, NSA Wednesday| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/02/12/rand-paul-files-suit-against-obama-nsa-today/|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 12, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Carroll|first=James R.|title=Rand Paul files lawsuit against NSA, President Obama over phone surveillance| url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20140212/NEWS01/302120057/Rand-Paul-files-lawsuit-against-NSA-President-Obama-over-phone-surveillance|newspaper=Courier-Journal|date=February 12, 2014}} Commenting on the lawsuit at a press conference, Paul said, "I'm not against the NSA, I'm not against spying, I'm not against looking at phone records... I just want you to go to a judge, have an individual's name and [get] a warrant. That's what the Fourth Amendment says." He also said there was no evidence the surveillance of phone metadata had stopped terrorism. Critics, including Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz{{cite news|last=Klimas|first=Jacqueline|title=Rand Paul pandering to GOP with NSA lawsuit, former Dem governor says| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/feb/12/ed-rendell-rand-paul-pandering-gop-nsa-lawsuit/|newspaper=Washington Times|date=February 12, 2014}} and Steven Aftergood, the director of the American Scientists' Project on Government Secrecy, called the lawsuit a political "stunt". Paul's political campaign organization said that the names of members of the public who went to Paul's websites and signed on as potential class-action participants would be available in the organization's database for future campaign use.{{cite news|last=Ballhaus|first=Rebecca|title=Rand Paul files class action lawsuit over NSA surveillance|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2014/02/12/rand-paul-files-class-action-lawsuit-over-nsa-surveillance|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 12, 2014}} On the announcement of the filing of the lawsuit, Mattie Fein, the spokeswoman for and former wife of attorney [[Bruce Fein]], complained that Fein's intellectual contribution to the lawsuit had been stolen and that he had not been properly paid for his work.{{cite news|last=Milbank|first=Dana|title=E-mails back claim that Sen. Rand Paul 'stole' NSA lawsuit|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2014/02/13/e-mails-back-claim-that-sen-rand-paul-stole-nsa-lawsuit|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=February 13, 2014}} Paul's representatives denied the charge, and Fein issued a statement saying that Mattie Fein had not been authorized to speak for him on the matter and that he had in fact been paid for his work on the lawsuit. Paul is co-author of a book entitled ''[[The Tea Party Goes to Washington]]'' (2011)''The Tea Party Goes to Washington'', Nashville: Center Street, 2011. 254 pp.{{cite news|last=Lowman|first=Stephen|title=Every Congress member to get Rand Paul's book|work=The Washington Post|date=February 22, 2011| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-bookworm/2011/02/every_member_of_congress_is_ge.html|access-date=March 5, 2011}} and also the author of ''[[Government Bullies|Government Bullies: How Everyday Americans Are Being Harassed, Abused, and Imprisoned by the Feds]]'' (2012).{{ASIN | 1455522759 }} Paul was included in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine's]] [[Time 100|world's 100 most influential people]], for 2013 and 2014.{{cite web|last=Gavin|first=Patrick|title=Politicians line Time's 100 list| url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/04/times-100-list-90271.html|publisher=''Politico''|access-date=April 18, 2013|date=April 18, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Lesniewski|first=Niels|title=Paul, Gillibrand Represent the Senate on Time's '100 Most Influential'| url=http://blogs.rollcall.com/wgdb/paul-gillibrand-represent-the-senate-on-times-100-most-influential/?dcz=|publisher=''Roll Call''|access-date=August 19, 2014|date=April 24, 2014}} He is also a contributor to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine.{{cite web| url=http://time.com/author/sen-rand-paul/ |title=Sen. Rand Paul |publisher=Time.com |date= |access-date=March 20, 2017}} ==Election to U.S. Senate== {{Main|United States Senate election in Kentucky, 2010}} ===Primary campaign=== [[File:Rand Paul in Hawesville by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Rand Paul speaking at a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] rally in [[Hawesville, Kentucky]], on November 21, 2009]] [[File:Rand Paul at Bowman Field by Gage Skidmore.jpg|right|thumb|Rand Paul greeting supporters at [[Bowman Field (airport)|Bowman Field]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]] on November 1, 2010.]] At the beginning of 2009, there was movement by political supporters of his father to [[Draft (politics)|draft]] Paul in a bid to replace beleaguered Republican Kentucky senator [[Jim Bunning]]. Paul's potential candidacy was discussed in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/03/ron-paul-defend.html |title=Ron Paul defends earmarks, says anti-pork McCain is just grandstanding |work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 11, 2009 |access-date=November 3, 2010}} and locally in the Kentucky press.[http://kywordsmith.com/#/rand-paul-issues/4533680792 "Rand Paul Set To Launch"] {{webarchive| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016134135/http://kywordsmith.com/ |date=October 16, 2015 }}, www.kywordsmith.com. May 9, 2009 Paul's father said, "Should Senator Bunning decide not to run, I think Rand would make a great U.S. Senator."{{cite news|title=Congressman Paul's Statement on His Son Rand Paul|last=Martin| first= T.|work=Pediatrics Week|date=March 21, 2009}} On April 15, 2009, Paul gave his first political speech as a potential candidate at a Tea Party rally held in his town of Bowling Green, Kentucky, where more than 700 people had gathered in support of the Tea Party movement.''The Tea Party Goes to Washington'', Nashville: Center Street, 2011. On May 1, 2009, Paul said that if Bunning, whose fundraising in 2009 matched his poor numbers in opinion polling for the 2010 election,{{Cite news| url=http://www.fivethirtyeight.com/2009/05/bunning-retirement-might-not-save-gop.html|title=Bunning Retirement Might Not Save GOP in Kentucky|agency=FiveThirtyEight.com|first=Nate|last=Silver|date=May 1, 2009}} declined to seek a third term, he would almost certainly run in the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] primary to succeed him,{{Cite news|url=http://www.wbko.com/news/headlines/44184752.html|title=Dr. Rand Paul Ready To Enter Primary For Bunning's Seat|agency=WBKO|date=May 1, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120529140108/http://www.wbko.com/news/headlines/44184752.html|archivedate=May 29, 2012|df=mdy-all}} and formed an [[exploratory committee]] soon after, while still promising to stay out of the race if Bunning ultimately decided to run for reelection. Paul made this announcement on [[MSNBC|MSNBC's]] ''[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]'', though a Kentucky news site first broke the news.[http://kywordsmith.com/#/paul-forms-exploratary-cmte/4533578818 "Rand Paul To Form Exploratory Committee For U.S. Senate Bid..."] {{webarchive| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016134135/http://kywordsmith.com/ |date=October 16, 2015 }}, www.kywordsmith.com. May 14, 2009 On July 28, 2009, Bunning announced that he would not run for reelection in the face of insufficient fundraising. The announcement left only Paul and [[Secretary of State of Kentucky|Secretary of State]] [[Trey Grayson]] as the remaining candidates for the Republican nomination,{{cite web|last=Memoli |first=Mike | url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/politics_nation/2009/06/ky_sen_potential_bunning_chall.html |title=Politics Nation – KY Sen: Potential Bunning Challenger Passes On Race |publisher=RealClearPolitics |date=June 15, 2009 |access-date=May 19, 2010}} with Paul announcing on August 5, 2009, that he would officially run for the U.S. Senate as a Republican. The announcement was made through a series of national TV events, radio, and other programs, as well as newspapers in Kentucky.{{cite web |last=Gerth |first=Joseph |date=August 5, 2009 | url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20090805/NEWS0106/908050401/Paul+says+he+will+run+for+Senate |title=Paul says he will run for Senate |work=Courier-Journal |access-date=August 5, 2009}}{{cite web |last=Giroux |first=Greg |date=August 5, 2009 |url=http://blogs.cqpolitics.com/eyeon2010/2009/08/rand-paul-declares-candidacy-f.html |title=Rand Paul Declares Candidacy For Kentucky Senate Seat |work=[[CQ Politics]] |access-date=August 7, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}{{dead link|date=July 2018|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{cite news|last=Keck |first=Kristi |date=August 6, 2009 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/06/kentucky.senate.paul/ |title=Ron Paul's son following in father's footsteps |publisher=CNN |access-date=August 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809123009/http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/06/kentucky.senate.paul/ |archivedate=August 9, 2009 |df=mdy }} On August 20, 2009, Paul's supporters planned a [[moneybomb]] to kick off his campaign. The official campaign took in $433,509 in 24 hours. His website reported that this set a new record in Kentucky's political fundraising history in a 24-hour period.{{cite web | url=http://www.randpaul2010.com/2009/08/rand-bomb-breaks-record/ |title=Rand Bomb Breaks Record |publisher=Randpaul2010.com |date=August 22, 2009 |access-date=November 3, 2010}} A second "moneybomb" was held on September 23, 2009, to counter a D.C. fundraiser being held for primary opponent Trey Grayson, by 23 Republican United States Senators.[http://bluegrasspolitics.bloginky.com/2009/08/31/web-site-promotes-fight-to-raise-money-for-paul/ "Lexington Herald-Leader – Web site promotes 'fight' to raise money for Paul"], Bluegrass Politics September 1, 2009 The theme was a [[Ultimate Fighting Championship|UFC]] "fight" between "We the People" and the "D.C. Insiders".[http://www.kentuckyfight.com/ "Kentucky Fight – Rand vs. Trey"], kentuckyfight.com September 1, 2009 Later in the campaign, Paul claimed his pledge to not take money from lobbyists and Senators who had voted for the bailout was only a "primary pledge";{{cite news|last=Schreiner|first=Bruce|title=Rand Paul flips, seeks money from bailout senators| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/9139316|newspaper=The Guardian|date=June 23, 2010|location=London}} he subsequently held a fundraiser in Washington, D.C., with the same Senators who had been the target of the September 23, 2009, "moneybomb". Paul ended up raising some $3 million during the primary period. Paul's fundraising was aided by his father's network of supporters. Although Grayson was considered the frontrunner in July 2009,Jack Brammer [http://bluegrasspolitics.bloginky.com/2009/07/28/some-conservatives-skeptical-of-grayson/ Some conservatives wary of Grayson] ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' July 28, 2009 Paul found success characterizing Grayson as a "career politician" and challenging Grayson's conservatism. Paul ran an ad in February that made an issue out of Grayson's September 2008 admission that he voted for Bill Clinton when he was 20 years old.Jack Brammer [http://www.kentucky.com/2010/02/27/1158455/paul-attempts-to-tie-grayson-to.html Senate ads trade barbs on defense] ''[[Lexington Herald-Leader]]'' February 27. 2010 [[James Dobson]], a Christian This money influx was in addition to the money spent by the candidates themselves: $6 million by Paul and $4.7 million by Conway.{{cite news|last=Steitzer|first=Stephanie|title=Outside groups spend big in U.S. Senate race| url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20101029/NEWS0106/310290083?nclick_check=1|newspaper=Courier-Journal|date=October 29, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Super PACs|url=http://reporting.sunlightfoundation.com/outside-spending/race/KY-Senate|publisher=Sunlight Foundation|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723051839/http://reporting.sunlightfoundation.com/outside-spending/race/KY-Senate|archivedate=July 23, 2012|df=mdy-all}} On June 28, 2010, Paul supporters held their first post-primary online fundraising drive, this time promoted as a "money blast".[http://www.gorandgo.com/ "GoRandGo.com – Road to Victory Money Blast"] {{webarchive| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522015721/http://www.gorandgo.com/ |date=May 22, 2010 }}, gorandgo.com/ June 7, 2010[http://www.whas11.com/news/local/Rand-Paul-supporters-plan-Moneyblast-95745464.html "Rand Paul supporters plan 'Moneyblast'"] {{webarchive| url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610221837/http://www.whas11.com/news/local/Rand-Paul-supporters-plan-Moneyblast-95745464.html |date=June 10, 2010 }}, June 7, 2010 Paul's campaign got off to a rough start after his comments on the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]] stirred controversy.Thompson, Krissah and Dan Balz. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/20/AR2010052003500.html "Rand Paul comments about civil rights stir controversy"], ''The Washington Post'', May 21, 2010 Paul stated that he favored 9 out of 10 titles of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, but that had he been a senator during the 1960s, he would have raised some questions on the constitutionality of [[Civil Rights Act of 1964#Title II|Title II]] of the Act.{{cite web|work=All Things Considered | url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126985068 |title=Rand Paul Says He Has A Tea Party 'Mandate{{'-}} |publisher=NPR |date=May 19, 2010 |access-date=September 10, 2010}} Paul said that he abhors racism, and that he would have marched with [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] to repeal [[Jim Crow laws]]. |url=http://www.whas11.com/community/blogs/political-blog/Rand-Paul-sits-down-with-Joe-Arnold-to-address-recent-controversial-statements-94665159.html |title=More raw video: Rand Paul sits down with |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527092834/http://www.whas11.com/community/blogs/political-blog/Rand-Paul-sits-down-with-Joe-Arnold-to-address-recent-controversial-statements-94665159.html |archivedate=May 27, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web| url=http://www.randpaul2010.com/2010/05/rand-paul-sets-the-record-straight/ |title=Rand Paul Sets the Record Straight |publisher=Randpaul2010.com simultaneously in the House of Representatives.{{cite news|last=Douglas|first=William|title=Father watches with pride as Rand Paul becomes U.S. senator|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]| date=January 5, 2011| url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2011/01/05/106256/father-watches-with-pride-as-rand.html#storylink=misearch|access-date=January 29, 2011}} Paul was assigned to be on the [[United States Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources|Energy and Natural Resources]], [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions|Health, Education, Labor and Pensions]], [[United States Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs|Homeland Security and Government Affairs]], and [[United States Senate Committee on Small Business and Entrepreneurship|Small Business]] committees.{{cite news|title=Four committee assignments for Rand Paul|work=Lexington Herald-Leader|date=January 28, 2011| url=http://www.kentucky.com/2011/01/28/1614138/four-committee-assignments-for.html|access-date=January 29, 2011}} Paul also formed the [[Tea Party Caucus#Members of Senate Caucus|Senate Tea Party Caucus]] with [[Jim DeMint]] and [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]] as its inaugural members.{{cite news|last=Sonmez|first=Felicia|title=Rand Paul announces Senate Tea Party Caucus|work=The Washington Post|date=January 14, 2011| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2011/01/rand-paul-announces-senate-tea.html|access-date=January 29, 2011}} His first legislative proposal was to cut $500 billion from federal spending in one year. This proposal included cutting the [[United States Department of Education|Department of Education]] by 83 percent and the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] by 43 percent, as well as folding the [[United States Department of Energy|Department of Energy]] into the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] and eliminating the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|Department of Housing and Urban Development]]. Seven independent agencies would be eliminated and food stamps would be cut by 30 percent. Under Paul's proposal, defense spending would be reduced by 6.5 percent and [[international aid]] would be eliminated.{{cite news|last=Straub|first=Bill|title=Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul rolls out budget ax|work=[[Evansville Courier & Press]]|date=January 28, 2011|url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2011/jan/27/sen-paul-rolls-out-budget-ax/|access-date=January 29, 2011}}; {{cite news|last=Carroll|first=James R.|date=January 25, 2011|title=Senator Rand Paul seeks $500 billion in federal spending cuts|work=The Courier-Journal|location=Louisville, Kentucky|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/2248953991.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+25%2C+2011&author=James+R+Carroll&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=n%2Fa&desc=Senator+Rand+Paul+seeks+%24500+billion+in+federal+spending+cuts|access-date=January 31, 2011}}; {{cite news| last= Freddoso| first= David| date= January 26, 2011| title= A detailed look at the Rand Paul spending bill| work= [[The Washington Examiner]]| url= http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/beltway-confidential/2011/01/detailed-look-rand-paul-spending-bill| access-date= April 9, 2011| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110511125605/http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/beltway-confidential/2011/01/detailed-look-rand-paul-spending-bill| archive-date= May 11, 2011| dead-url= yes| df= mdy-all}} He later proposed a five-year budget plan intended to balance the budget.{{cite news|last=Bruce|first=Mary|title=Sen. Paul Unveils 5-Year Budget Plan: Eliminates Four Federal Agencies|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=March 17, 2011| url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2011/03/sen-paul-unveils-5-year-budget-plan-eliminates-four-federal-agencies.html|access-date=March 24, 2011}} In February, Paul was one of two Republicans to vote against extending three key provisions of the [[Patriot Act|USA PATRIOT Act]] ([[roving wiretap]]s, searches of business records, and conducting surveillance of "lone wolves" — individuals not linked to terrorist groups).{{cite news|last=Sonmez|first=Felicia|title=Senate passes short-term extension of Patriot Act provisions|work=The Washington Post|date =February 15, 2011| url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2011/02/senate-to-vote-tuesday-on-shor.html|access-date=February 17, 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/26/patriot-act-extension-passes-senate_n_867736.html|access-date=May 26, 2011|newspaper=[[HuffPost|The Huffington Post]]|date=May 26, 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yz8uVD4V?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/05/26/patriot-act-extension-passes-senate_n_867736.html|archivedate=May 27, 2011|first=Alexander|last=Belenky|title=Patriot Act Extension Passes Senate, Rand Paul Amendments Fail|deadurl=yes}} On March 2, Paul was one of nine senators to vote against a stopgap bill that cut $4 billion from the budget and temporarily prevent a [[Government shutdown in the United States|government shutdown]], saying that it did not cut enough from the budget.{{cite news|last=Middleton|first=Neil|title=Yarmuth and Paul vote no on stopgap spending bill|publisher=[[WYMT-TV]]|date=March 2, 2011}} One week later, he voted against the Democratic and Republican budget proposals to keep funding the federal government, saying that both bills did not cut enough spending. Both bills failed to pass the Senate. He later voted against stopgap measures on March 17 and April 8, both of which passed the senate.{{cite news|last=Jaffe|first=Matthew|title=Kickin' the Can: Senate Passes Stop-Gap Spending Plan, Buys Lawmakers Three More Weeks To Solve Funding Mess|publisher=ABC News|date =March 17, 2011| url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2011/03/kickin-the-can-senate-passes-stop-gap-spending-plan-buys-lawmakers-three-more-weeks-to-solve-funding.html|access-date=April 9, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Scott|title=Rand Paul opposes temporary stopgap|work=Politico|date=April 9, 2011|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/glennthrush/0411/Rand_Paul_opposes_temporary_stopgap_.html|access-date=April 9, 2011}} On April 14, he was one of 19 senators to vote against a budget that cut $38.5 billion from the budget and fund the government for the remainder of the fiscal year.{{cite news|last=Bowman|first=Quinn|title=House, Senate Pass Bipartisan Budget Deal to Fund Government|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date =April 14, 2011|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/04/house-passes-385-budget-deal-to-fund-government.html|access-date=May 26, 2011}} Paul voiced opposition to U.S. intervention in the [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|Libyan Civil War]] and has criticized President Obama for not gaining congressional consent for [[Operation Odyssey Dawn]].{{cite news| last= Straub| first= Bill| title=Kentucky Senator Paul berates Obama for 'cavalierly taking us to war{{'-}}|work=Evansville Courier & Press|date=March 30, 2011| url=http://www.courierpress.com/news/2011/mar/30/kentucky-senator-paul-berates-obama-cavalierly-tak/|access-date=April 14, 2011 }}; {{cite news|last =Sonmez|first =Felicia|date=March 17, 2011|title=Rand Paul opposes U.S. military involvement in Libya|work=The Washington Post| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/2chambers/post/rand-paul-opposes-us-military-involvement-in-libya/2011/03/17/ABkw6jl_blog.html|access-date=April 14, 2011}} During the [[United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011|debt ceiling crisis]], the Senator stated that he would only support raising the debt ceiling if a [[balanced budget amendment]] was enacted.{{cite news|last=Klein|first=Rick|title=Sen. Rand Paul: No Debt Ceiling Increase Without Balanced Budget Amendment| url=http://blogs.abcnews.com/thenote/2011/06/sen-rand-paul-no-debt-ceiling-increase-without-balanced-budget-amendment.html|publisher=ABC News|access-date=August 3, 2011|date=June 30, 2011}} Paul was a supporter of the [[Cut, Cap and Balance Act]], which was [[Table (parliamentary procedure)|tabled]] by Democratic opposition.{{cite news|last=Hayward|first=John|title=Cut, Cap, and Balance Killed| url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=45039|work=[[Human Events]]|access-date=August 3, 2011|date=July 22, 2011}} On August 3, Paul voted against a bill that would raise the debt ceiling.{{cite news|last=Marchmon|first=Jay|title=Rand Paul reacts to passage of debt ceiling bill|url=http://www.wpsdlocal6.com/news/local/Rand-Paul-reacts-to-passage-of-debt-ceiling-bill-126594128.html|publisher=[[WPSD-TV]]|access-date=August 3, 2011|date=August 2, Calls for No Confidence on Geithner| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2011/09/07/rand-paul-calls-for-no-confidence-vote-on-geithner/|access-date=September 8, 2011|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=September 8, 2011}} Later that month, Paul blocked legislation that would strengthen safety rules for oil and gas pipelines, because, he stated, the bill was not strong enough.{{cite url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/10/fight-erupts-in-congress-over-pipeline-safety-legislation-.html|access-date=October 28, 2011|work=Los Angeles Times|date=October 5, 2011}} In October, Paul blocked a bill that would provide $36 million in benefits for elderly and disabled refugees, saying that he was concerned that it could be used to aid domestic terrorists. This was in response to two alleged terrorists who came to the United States through a refugee program and were receiving welfare benefits when they were arrested in 2011 in Paul's hometown of Bowling Green.{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Scott|title=Rand Paul blocking refugee funds| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1011/65142.html|access-date=October 4, 2011|work=Politico|date=October 5, 2011}} Paul lifted his hold on the bill after Democratic leaders promised to hold a Congressional hearing into how individuals are selected for refugee status and request an investigation on how the two suspects were admitted in the country through a refugee program.{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Scott|title=Rand Paul ends hold on SSI benefits| url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1011/65142.html|access-date=October 28, 2011|work=Politico|date=October 17, 2011}} In June 2012, Paul endorsed [[Mitt Romney]] after it became apparent that he would be the Republican nominee for the 2012 presidential election.{{cite news| url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/burns-haberman/2012/06/rand-paul-endorses-romney-125624|title=Rand Paul endorses Romney|date=June 7, 2012|publisher=POLITICO}} However, he was later vocal about his disagreements with Romney on a number of policies.{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/10/opinion/rand-paul-romney-foreign-policy/|title=Rand Paul: Romney's wrong on Middle East, defense spending|date=October 10, 2012|publisher=CNN}} ===113th Congress (2013–2015)=== For the 113th Congress, Paul was added to the [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Foreign Relations committee]] and retained his spot on the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, Homeland Security and Government Affairs, and Small Business committees.{{cite web|last=McCarthy|first=Daniel|title=Rand Paul on the Foreign Relations Committee – and What It Means| url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/rand-paul-on-foreign-relations-committee/|work=The American Conservative|access-date=March 29, 2013|date=January 3, 2013}} On March 6–7, 2013, Paul engaged in a [[Filibuster in the United States Senate|filibuster]] to delay voting on the nomination of [[John O. Brennan]] as the [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency]]. Paul questioned the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration's]] use of [[unmanned aerial vehicle|drones]] and the stated legal justification for their potential use within the United States. Paul held the floor for 12 hours and 52 minutes.{{cite news|title=Rand Paul Ends Epic Mr. Smith-Style Filibuster After More Than 12 Hours| url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2013/03/06/rand_paul_is_waging_an_epic_mr_smith_style_filibuster_right_now.html| first= Josh |last= Voorhees|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|access-date=March 7, 2013|date=March 7, 2013}} He ceded to several Republican senators and Democratic senator, [[Ron Wyden]], who generally also questioned drone usage.{{cite news|title=Sen. Paul holds floor for hours in filibuster of CIA nominee, over drone concerns| url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/03/06/sen-paul-holds-floor-for-hours-in-filibuster-cia-nominee-over-drone-concerns/|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=March 6, 2013|access-date=March 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Ewing|first=Philip|title=Rand Paul pulls plug on nearly 13-hour filibuster on drones | url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/03/rand-paul-filibuster-john-brennan-cia-nominee-88507.html|work=Politico|access-date=March 6, 2013|date=March 6, 2013}} Paul said his purpose was to challenge drone policy in general and specifically as it related to noncombatants on U.S. soil. He requested a pledge from the Administration that noncombatants would not be targeted on U.S. soil.{{cite news|last=Michaels|first=Jim|title=Rand Paul ends epic filibuster over Brennan| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2013/03/07/rand-paul-brennan-filibuster/1969869/|work=USA Today|access-date=March 7, 2013|date=March 7, 2013}} Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] responded that the President is not authorized to deploy [[extrajudicial punishment]] without [[Due Process Clause|due process]], against non-combatant citizens. Paul answered that he was "quite happy" with the response.{{cite news|title=Rand Paul 'happy' with drone response| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/07/obama-administration-responds-to-paul-on-drones/|publisher=CNN|access-date=March 3, 2013|date=March 3, 2013}} The filibuster was ended with a [[cloture]] vote of 81 to 16, and Brennan was confirmed by the Senate with a vote of 63 to 34.[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/08/us/politics/brennan-confirmed-to-lead-the-cia.html "Brennan Confirmed to Lead the C.I.A."] Sarah Wheaton. ''The New York Times''. March 7, 2013. Retrieved November 1, 2013 [[File:Rand Paul Filibuster.png|left|thumb|Rand Paul speaking during [[filibuster]] on the [[United States Senate|Senate]] floor on March 6, 2013.]] In March 2013, Paul, with Senators [[Ted Cruz]] and [[Mike Lee (American politician)|Mike Lee]], threatened another filibuster, this one opposing any legislative proposals to expand federal [[Gun control#Gun control in the United States|gun control]] measures.{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Jonathan|title=Rand Paul and Ted Cruz threaten filibuster on guns| url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/03/rand-paul-and-ted-cruz-threaten-filibuster-on-guns-89299.html|work=Politico|access-date=March 25, 2013|date=March 25, 2013}} The filibuster was attempted on April 11, 2013, but was dismissed by cloture, in a 68–31 vote.{{cite news|title=Gun bill clears Senate hurdle as filibuster falls short| url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/04/11/gun-bill-clears-senate-hurdle-as-filibuster-falls-short | work=Fox News | date=April 11, 2013}} Also in March 2013, Paul endorsed fellow Kentucky Republican Senator [[Mitch McConnell]]'s [[United States Senate election in Kentucky, 2014|2014 re-election campaign]].{{cite news|last=Howley|first=Patrick|title=Rand Paul endorses Mitch McConnell in 2014 Senate race, won't back tea party challenge| url=http://dailycaller.com/2013/03/27/rand-paul-helps-squash-tea-party-challenge-to-mcconnell/|access-date=August 9, 2013|newspaper=The Daily Caller|date=March 27, 2013}} McConnell had previously hired Paul's 2010 campaign manager, [[Jesse Benton]], as his own campaign manager.{{cite news|last=Trinko|first=Katrina|title=From Rand to Mitch| url=http://www.nationalreview.com/article/354807/rand-mitch-katrina-trinko|access-date=August 9, 2013|newspaper=National Review|date=July 31, 2014}} Paul's endorsement was seen as a major win for McConnell in avoiding a challenge in the Republican primary. In response to [[Detroit]]'s [[Detroit bankruptcy|declaration of bankruptcy]], Paul stated he would not allow the government to attempt to bail out Detroit. In a phone interview with [[Breitbart News]] on July 19, 2013, Paul said, "I basically say he is bailing them out over my dead body, because we don't have any money in Washington." Paul said he thought a federal bailout would send the wrong message to other cities with financial problems.{{cite news|last=Arkin|first=James|title=Rand Paul: No government bailout for Detroit| url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/07/detroit-bankruptcy-bailout-rand-paul-94478.html|work=Politico|access-date=October 16, 2013|date=July 19, 2013}} In September, Paul stated that the United States should avoid military intervention in the ongoing [[Syrian Civil War]].{{cite news|last=Clary|first=Greg|title=Rand Paul: U.S. involvement in Syria a 'mistake{{'-}}| url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2013/09/01/rand-paul-u-s-involvement-in-syria-a-mistake/|publisher=CNN|access-date=September 16, 2013|date=September 1, 2013}} In an [[op-ed]], Paul disputed the Obama administration's claims that the threat of military force caused Syria's government to consider turning over its chemical weapons, instead arguing that the opposition to military action in Syria, and the delay that it caused, led to diplomatic progress.{{cite news|last=Blake|first=Aaron|title=Rand Paul: Opposition to military action led to Syria diplomacy| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/09/13/rand-paul-opposition-to-military-action-led-to-syria-diplomacy/|work=The Washington Post|access-date=October 16, 2013|date=September 13, 2013}} In October 2013, Paul was the subject of some controversy when it was discovered that he had plagiarized from [[Wikipedia]] part of a speech in support of [[Virginia gubernatorial election, 2013|Virginia gubernatorial candidate]] [[Ken Cuccinelli]]. Referencing the movie ''[[Gattaca]]'', Paul quoted almost verbatim from the Wikipedia article about the film without citing the source.{{cite news|last=Carroll|first=James R.|title=Sen. Rand Paul warns science could be used to alter gene pool|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20131028/NEWS01/310280057/Sen-Rand-Paul-warns-science-abortion-could-used-eliminate-undesirables|work=The Courier-Journal|location=Louisville, KY|access-date=October 28, 2013|date=October 28, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Yarvitz|first=Michael|title=The Rand Paul plagiarism read-along!| url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/catching-rand-paul-plagiarizing-home-edition|work=The Rachel Maddow Show|publisher=MSNBC|date=October 29, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Contorno|first=Steve|title=Rachel Maddow says Rand Paul's 'Gattaca' speech 'was totally ripped off of Wikipedia{{'-}}| url=http://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2013/nov/01/rachel-maddow/rachel-maddow-says-rand-pauls-gattaca-speech-was-t/|newspaper=PolitiFact (Tampa Bay Times)|date=November 1, 2013|author2=Kliegman, Julie}} Evidence soon surfaced that Paul had copied sentences in a number of his other speeches nearly verbatim from other authors without giving credit to the original sources,{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Jake|title=Critics pounce on Rand Paul's borowed language| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-250_162-57610423/critics-pounce-on-rand-pauls-borrowed-language/|newspaper=CBS News|date=November 1, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Jonathan|title=Senator Rand Paul faces new charges of plagiarism| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/05/us/politics/senator-rand-paul-faces-new-charges-of-plagiarism.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=November 4, 2013}} including in the speech he had given as the Tea Party rebuttal to the president's 2013 State of the Union address. news|last=Kaczynski|first=Andrew|title=Three pages of Rand Paul's book were plagiarized from think tanks| Action Conference]] (CPAC) in [[National Harbor, Maryland]], on March 14, 2013]] ===Background=== [[File:Rand Paul (22525600570).jpg|thumb|Paul speaking at a campaign rally, October 2015]] Paul was considered a potential candidate for the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|Republican nomination]] for the [[President of the United States|Presidency of the United States]] since at least January 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/01/rand-paul-gop-must-evolve-and-adapt-86473.html|title=Rand Paul: GOP must 'evolve and adapt{{'-}}|first=Mackenzie|last=Weinger|work=Politico|date=January 28, 2013|access-date=August 20, 2013}} He delivered the Tea Party response to [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama's]] [[State of the Union address]] on February 13, 2013,{{cite news| url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/02/tea-party-rebuttal-text-of-rand-paul-response-87557.html |title=Tea party State of the Union 2013 rebuttal: Rand Paul response (full text)|work=Politico|date=February 13, 2013|access-date=August 20, 2013}} while [[Marco Rubio]] gave the official Republican response. This prompted some pundits to call that date the start of the 2016 Republican primaries.{{cite news|work=[[All Things Considered]]|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/02/14/172034468/rand-paul-big-governments-not-a-friend-to-those-who-are-trying-to-get-ahead|title=Rand Paul: 'Big Government's Not A Friend To Those Who Are Trying To Get Ahead{{'-}}|publisher=NPR|date=February 14, 2013|access-date=August 20, 2013}} That year, he spoke at the [[Conservative Political Action Conference]] in Washington D.C., where he won the 2016 Presidential straw poll. Paul went on to win the straw poll for the next two years as well, leading to some considering Paul to be a front runner for the nomination, although CPAC attendees are typically considered younger and more libertarian-minded than average Republican voters.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2015/02/28/rand-paul-wins-2015-cpac-straw-poll|title=Rand Paul wins 2015 CPAC straw poll|publisher=[[Fox News]]|access-date=March 1, 2015|date=February 28, 2015}}{{cite journal|title=Rand Paul wins CPAC straw poll, with Scott Walker a close second|journal=The Washington Post|date=February 28, 2015|last=Cha|first=Ariana|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/02/28/rand-paul-wins-cpac-straw-poll-narrowly-topping-walker|access-date=March 2, 2015|quote="A candidate's popularity with the Conservative Political Action Conference hasn't necessarily been a great predictor of his or her success with the larger GOP electorate, as attendees tend to have a stronger libertarian bent than the Republican majority."}}{{cite journal|title=Senator Rand Paul wins straw poll in boost to 2016 presidential prospects|journal=Reuters|date=February 28, 2015|last=Holland|first=Steve|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/01/us-randpaul-idUSKBN0LW0YY20150301|access-date=March 2, 2015 |quote="Whether the victory for Paul will have long-lasting benefit is unclear since his libertarian views may not have broad appeal in the Republican Party."}} In a speech at the GOP Freedom Summit in April 2014, Paul insisted that the GOP has to broaden its appeal in order to grow as a party. To do so, he said it cannot be the party of "fat cats, rich people and Wall Street" and that the conservative movement has never been about rich people or privilege, "we are the middle class", he said. Paul also said that conservatives must present a message of justice and concern for the unemployed and be against government surveillance to attract new people to the movement, including the young, Hispanics, and blacks.{{cite news|title=Obamacare' under attack as conservatives eye 2016|url=https://news.yahoo.com/obamacare-under-attack-conservatives-eye-2016-200658669--election.html|agency=Associated Press|access-date=April 14, 2014}} During the 2014 election, Paul launched a social media campaign titled "Hillary's Losers" which was meant to highlight many of the Democratic candidates that lost their bids for the U.S. Senate despite endorsements from [[Hillary Clinton]]. Clinton was [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016|also a candidate for President]] and eventually won the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 2016|Democratic Party's nomination]], going on to lose to [[Donald Trump]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|general election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/nov/7/rand-paul-clinton-democrats-became-hillarys-losers|title=Rand Paul: 'Clinton Democrats' became 'Hillary's losers' during election landslide|publisher=Washington Times|access-date=February 4, 2015|date=November 7, 2014|last=Sherfinski|first=David}} Paul began to assemble his campaign team, setting up campaign offices and hiring his campaign manager in the beginning of 2015, fueling speculation that he was preparing to enter the Presidential race.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2015/01/13/rand-paul-announces-campaign-manager-as-he-ramps-up-2016-campaign|title=Rand Paul announces campaign manager for likely 2016 campaign|access-date=February 4, 2015|date=January 13, 2015|work=The Washington Post|author=Costa, Robert}} Paul officially announced his presidential candidacy on April 7, 2015. Within a day of his announcement, Paul raised $1 million.{{cite news|last1=Ballhaus|first1=Rebecca|title=Rand Paul Sprints to $1 Million Fundraising Mark| url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2015/04/08/rand-paul-sprints-to-1-million-fundraising-mark/|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=April 8, 2015}} ===Senate re-election=== {{See also|United States Senate election in Kentucky, 2016}} In April 2011, Paul filed to run for re-election to his Senate seat in 2016.{{cite web|title=Rand Paul files for reelection race five years away | Rand Paul Suspends Republican Presidential Campaign|publisher=NBCNews.com|date=February 3, 2016|access-date=July 30, 2018|author=Caldwell, Leigh Ann}} ==Political positions== {{Main|Political positions of Rand Paul}} [[File:Rand Paul (6158000602).jpg|thumb|Paul being interviewed by [[Jerry Doyle]] at LPAC 2011 in Reno, Nevada, September 16, 2011]] A supporter of the [[Tea Party movement]],{{cite news|last=Fineman|first=Howard|title=Rand Paul Torn Between Tea Party Fire, White House Dreams| url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/12/rand-paul-president_n_3582315.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=July 12, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Tea party State of the Union 2013 rebuttal: Rand Paul response (full text, video)|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2013/02/tea-party-rebuttal-text-of-rand-paul-response-87557.html#ixzz2c5fLSz61|newspaper=Politico|date=February 12, 2013}} Paul has described himself as a "constitutional conservative".{{cite news|last=Solomon|first=Deborah|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/04/magazine/04fob-q4-t.html|title=Questions for Rand Paul – Tea Time Interview|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 23, 2010|date=March 29, 2010}} He is generally described as a [[libertarianism in the United States|libertarian]], a term he both embraced{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Martina|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/04/im-very-serious-about-running-ron-pauls-son-says|title='I'm very serious about running', Ron Paul's son says|publisher=CNN|access-date=November 15, 2010|date=May 4, 2010|quote=Like his father, the son also favors notions of limited government. He supports [[term limits]], a [[Balanced Budget Amendment#United States|balanced budget amendment]], and the [[Read the Bills Act]], in addition to the widespread reduction of federal spending and
